titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the James Montgomery Collection
titlestmt.author: by Beinecke Staff

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Thursday January 10, 2019 at 04:23

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The collection contains letters from James Montgomery to various friends, colleagues, and associates, including authors, publishers, and clergymen; recipients include John Aikin, Samuel Taylor Coleridge, Robert Hartley Davenport, George Williams Fulcher, Thomas Raffles, and Robert Southey. Much of the content relates to Montgomery's writings and publications, in particular his poetry and work for hymnals, though some of the letters are personal in nature. Also present is a small group of autograph manuscript poems and other writings by Montgomery, including two poems translated into Welsh. Reference material in the collection includes clippings about Montgomery, portrait engravings, and material pertaining to his life, death, and funeral proceedings, including a copy of The Death of James Montgomery, Esq. with a Sketch of his Life (1854).

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased as a collection from Maggs Bros. Ltd. on the Plain Fund, 1954. Five additions acquired by gift and purchase from various sources are noted at the folder level in the Collection Contents list.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The James Montgomery Collection is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: James Montgomery Collection. General Collection, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This finding aid was produced from previously existing cards in the Manuscripts Catalog, or from another inventory. All pertinent bibliographical information has been retained.
Former call number: MS Vault Montgomery

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The James Montgomery Collection primarily contains letters written by him to various friends, colleagues, and professional associates, as well as a group of his writings, and a selection of historical and reference material related to his life and death.

Series I holds letters to Montgomery's friends, fellow authors, his publishers, and various clergymen. Recipients include Samuel Taylor Coleridge, Barbara Hofland, and Hannah More, among many others. Multiple letters exist for several of his correspondents, including more than twenty sent to the author and editor (and medical doctor) John Aikin in London; these letters are the longest and most descriptive in the collection, with seven written on oversize sheets of paper. Other multiple letter sets are present for Robert Hartley Davenport (6), George Williams Fulcher (6), John Holland (5), Thomas Raffles (11), Robert Southey (4), and Miss Thompson (8). Most letters have the recipients' postal addresses as part of their document. Much of the content relates to Montgomery's writings and publications, in particular his poetry and work for hymnals, though some of the letters are personal in nature.

Series II holds a group of autograph manuscript poems and other writings by Montgomery, including two poems translated into Welsh. Series III holds clippings about Montgomery, portrait engravings, and material pertaining to his death and funeral proceedings, including a copy of The Death of James Montgomery, Esq. with a Sketch of his Life (1854).

bioghist.head: James Montgomery (1771-1854)
bioghist.p: James Montgomery was an English author, editor, and resident of Sheffield, England.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into three series: I. Letters from James Montgomery, 1789-1853. II. Writings of James Montgomery, 1821-1852. III. Other Papers, 1824-1920.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged in alphabetical order by recipient, followed by sixteen letters to unidentified recipients filed chronologically at the end.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter; a long letter to Dr. Aikin; Montgomery apologizes for not having replied previously, and deals with various matters, such as his school, his childhood, remarks on poetry, etc.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter; Montgomery mentions a poem he had hoped to enclose, his publishers Longman & Co., and a second edition of his works.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed; Montgomery thanks Dr. Aikin for superintending the second edition of his poems.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed; with regard to Montgomery's poems.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed; dealing with some poems; Montgomery makes a few corrections and alterations in the wording.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed; Montgomery thanks Dr. Aikin for superintending the third edition of his poems.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter; Montgomery refers to the publishers of the "Monthly Mirror"; Mr. Rhodes wishes to insert a memoir and portrait of Montgomery in this journal.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter; Montgomery discusses a critique of his poems that appeared in the Edinburgh Review .

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed; in this letter Montgomery recalls the time when he was associated with Campbell & Grahame.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed; written from Sheffield.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter; enclosing Part III of the poem, "The West Indies."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter; a long letter, together with the fourth part of the poem "The West Indies."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter; the letter is relative to a sketch of the history of Montgomery's mind, which Dr. Aikin has asked him to furnish.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed; Montgomery has made the personal acquaintance of Dr. Aikin, and thanks him for his kindness during a visit.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter; this letter, among other things, deals with a ship lost in a storm, and Montgomery has included a poem, "The Castaway Ship."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed; enclosing original manuscript of Canto I of The World Before the Flood .

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed; enclosing original manuscript of Canto II of The World Before the Flood .

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed; Montgomery enquires about Dr. Aikin's health. He also mentions "The West Indies."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed; Montgomery deals with certain poems, etc., in this letter.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed; a personal letter, in which he mentions Miss Aikin's visit to Edinburgh, etc.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed; written on a folder containing a poem, "The Peak Mountains" by "J. M." in two parts.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed; concerning the choice of a motto for Mr. Ball.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed; Montgomery states he has not found it convenient to engage himself upon any committee in behalf of gentleman offering themselves as candidates for Parliament, but he mentions the name of his friend Samuel Bailey.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter; Montgomery conveys his respects to Mr. and Mrs. Blackwell.

did.unittitle: Boyd, Joseph B., of Cincinnati, Ohio

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed; regarding a certain poem (no title given).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter; mentions Montgomery's poem, "Greenland."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter; written to a bookseller when Montgomery was 18, and he offers some poems for publication.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed; Montgomery tells Mr. Carder he has been much indisposed since his return from Scarborough, and deals with a certain poem.

did.unittitle: Chantrey, Francis Legatt, of Pimlico, London

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed; this letter was written by Montgomery to serve as an introduction for his friend, Rowland Hodgson, to Mr. Chantrey.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed; regarding Montgomery's "Hymn for Children." He tells Mr. Christy he can make use of it as he likes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter; Montgomery also encloses an original manuscript, "Lord Falkland's Dream."

did.unittitle: Coleridge, Samuel Taylor, of Grasmere, Kendal

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter; Montgomery informs Mr. Coleridge he has been able to obtain two subscribers to Mr. Coleridge's intended work.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed; Montgomery thanks his friend for his offer of help and financial assistance.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed; referring to a volume Mr. Cromek has sent Montgomery.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Six autograph letters and autograph letters, signed; Montgomery writes in regard to The Poetical Register , and various poems he submits for publication.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter; Montgomery conveys his respects and wonders if "she will have an early opportunity of enclosing a small parcel of Missionary Reports to Miss Rowntree of York."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed; Montgomery mentions Miss Gales' failing health in this letter.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed; Montgomery states he cannot be present at York owing to having received a letter from his sister announcing the serious illness of her son, and asking him to visit them at Bedford.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed; this letter is with regard to the Peckham Negro Friends Society and a school for adult Negroes in Jamaica

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed; this is with regard to some business with Cochrane & Co., and mentions Longman & Co.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed; regarding a sum of Â£10. Montgomery also refers to a course of lectures he has been asked to deliver.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed; Montgomery mentions the passing of a dear friend, Mr. George Bennet.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed; Montgomery thanks Mr. Fulcher for the "elegant little books." He also appends an autographed poem.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed; regarding some verses which Montgomery transmitted for Mr. Fulcher's "Annual."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed; Montgomery acknowledges Â£1.1.0. for a fund opened for the missionaries in Greenland.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed; Montgomery acknowledges two letters from Mr. Fulcher.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed; Montgomery acknowledges a donation of Â£2.2.0. and also sends a short poem, "The Dying Child's Request."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed; Montgomery asks that his name be added to the list of subscribers of Fulcher's "lady editor of a volume of poem to be published in aid of the suffering sick."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed; Montgomery states in this letter that as a boy he wrote a great many hymns.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed; together with hymn, "Father of Eternal Grace: Glorify Thyself in Me." Also an air, "Song of the Negro's Daughter."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter; Montgomery thanks him for the air he has adapted to his hymn. He also sets out a poem, "A Midnight Thought," and "Song of the Negro's Daughter."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter; enclosing poem, "The Dead Canary Bird." Accompanied by an engraved portrait of Montgomery.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed; Montgomery has to decline Mrs. Hare's request for some verses.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed; enclosing poem, "Children's Pennies, and apologizing for not having forwarded the poem before. Accompanied by a note regarding the poem by Sarah Hayward.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed; regarding Elizabeth Cooper's The Muses' Library .

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed; this is a letter of thanks for a gift.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed; regarding the return of an album to her. Accompanied by engraved portrait of Montgomery.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of James Hosmer Penniman, 1921; formerly part of the Penniman Memorial Library, Yale University.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed; with regard to certain poems by Mr. Roberts which appeared in the Sheffield newspapers.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed; written from Sheffield.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed; this deals with two manuscripts Mr. Holland has in hand.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed; the letter announces the death of Anne.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed; this letter is with regard to some matters appertaining to the museum.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed; a letter of thanks for a volume of poems which Mr. Howitt sent Montgomery.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed; Montgomery has been asked to attend a meeting of the Leeds Mechanic's Institute and Library.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed; regarding some stones sent to Montgomery. Written from 10, New Palace Yard, [London?].

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed; regarding the Gas Light Company's affairs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed; with regard to the Gas Light Company dividend, etc.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed; regarding the Reverend Hunter's son, who has made application as a candidate for the place of assistant to the House Surgeon of the Infirmary.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed; this is with regard to Election Day. Written from Fulneck, near Leeds.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed; regarding the lectures on poetry and general literature which Montgomery states he gave some years ago at the Royal Institution.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed; this refers to a lecture given by Montgomery at the Royal Institute in London.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed; Montgomery encloses a copy of the rules of the Mechanic's Library, and also mentions a Reading and Conversation Society.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed; regarding the return of proof sheets of a work by Montgomery.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed; Montgomery asks for a complete copy of his poems, and also a copy of the The Christian Psalmist and The Christian Poet to be sent to Miss Farrer of London.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed; Montgomery requests that certain books are sent to him.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter; Montgomery mentions in this letter a certain Mr. West, also Bishop Chase, and Kenyon College, Ohio.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed; Montgomery criticizes some poems by Mr. Manners.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed; regarding six lectures on poets which Montgomery is engaged to deliver at the Collegiate Institution at Liverpool.

did.unittitle: Montagu, Mrs. Basil, of Lincoln's Inn

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed; a long letter touching on various points, such as Mr. Montagu being called to the Chancery Bar.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed; a letter of farewell to his brother. Written from Hackney.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter; acknowledging receipt of certain sums of money for the fund on behalf of Mrs. Caterall and her children.

did.unittitle: Moxon, Edward, of Dover Street, London

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed; Montgomery thanks Mr. Moxon for a token sent him.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed; regarding Montgomery's upcoming appearance in Norton.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed; Montgomery requests his patronage for the Library for Mechanics and Apprentices of Sheffield.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed; with regard to a Mr. Brayham offering himself as candidate for Parliament. Montgomery says some words in his praise.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letters, signed; eleven letters written from Sheffield between March 29, 1807 and September 10, 1844.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter; dealing with a volume containing "Memoirs of Richard Reynolds."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed; to the secretary of the Antimonopoly Association of Liverpool, dealing with an invitation to the Great Free Trade Demonstration there.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed; regarding Mr. Carlisle, a London bookseller, who is being convicted for selling blasphemous publications.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed; Miss Reece has evidently asked Montgomery for some poems, and he replies "...if anything fit to send you comes into my mind, I shall be happy to please your correspondent and yourself."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter; Montgomery encloses the "long delayed" stanza "The Negro is Free."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter; regarding a poem written by Montgomery.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed; Montgomery criticizes some of Mr. Rodgers' verses.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter; a letter of thanks to Mr. and Mrs. Roscoe.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed; this letter deals with the affairs of the British Linen Co., and as Deputy Governor, Montgomery "begs leave to present a Memorial upon the same subject." On the reverse side is Mr. Ryder's reply, dated April 29, 1811.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed; regarding Montgomery's poem, "The Skylark."

did.unittitle: Smith, Miss, of The Mount, Sheffield

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter; Montgomery sends two volumes to Miss Smith, with his best respects.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter; written on a printed folder containing Montgomery's poem "The Peak Mountains." He mentions Southey's "Pilgrim's Progress."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter; Montgomery states he has been seriously ill. He mentions "Roderick, the Last of the Goths."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter; this letter deals with a memoir that Southey is writing of John Bunyan.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter; Montgomery apologizes for not having had an opportunity of visiting him, as he had been visiting various towns on the "occasion of the anniversaries of their respective Bible Societies..."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed; enquiring the terms for publishing a story.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed; this letter deals with The Blind Man and his Son .

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed; regarding Mr. Sterndale the bearer of this letter. Montgomery speaks on his behalf.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed; written from Hartshead.

did.unittitle: Thompson, Miss H., of Fargate, Sheffield

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed; Montgomery thanks Miss Thompson for her kind note, and refers to some verses by Byron.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed; announcing the death of Miss Elizabeth Gales.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter; Montgomery sends his respects to Miss Thompson, and mentions a certain hymn book.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed; Montgomery sends six copies of his Polyhymnia, or Select Airs by Celebrated Foreign Composers .

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed; regarding what he's reading.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter; a reply to an invitation to tea. Montgomery has to refuse. Written from Hartshead.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter; this letter regards Mr. Comey's letter in The Gentleman's Magazine , respecting a new edition of Thomson's The Seasons .

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed; Montgomery encloses Â£16 with this letter, to be placed to the credit of his account for stamps.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

did.unittitle: Wilkinson, Henry, of Endcliffe Hall, Sheffield

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed; written from The Mount, Sheffield.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter; with regard to a monthly meeting held the previous evening.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter; Montgomery thanks Mr. Wood for his invitation, but is unable to accept it.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed; written from The Mount, Sheffield.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Montgomery mentions Latin, Latin poetry, and his school days.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed; this letter deals with an account of Sheffield.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed; written from Sheffield. Delivered by a Mrs. Megson to a certain lady, in respect to negotiations between her brother and James Montgomery.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed; regarding his work, Polyhymnia, or Select Airs by Celebrated Foreign Composers . Montgomery requests that any copies remaining on hand are returned to him immediately.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed; regarding certain papers which Montgomery states he returns, at the same time apologizing for having "kept them so long."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed; dealing with some stanzas sent to Montgomery.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed; Montgomery states that this arrived during his absence from home. He mentions the secretary of the Sheffield Literary and Philosophical Society, and also the Rev. Jack Hunter.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed; Montgomery requests that 180 copies of his psalms and hymns are sent to Reverend Piccope in Manchester, and the order charged to the estate of Mrs. Cotterill.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter; regarding Mr. W. Saunders, a civil engineer. Montgomery, having known Mr. Saunders from his youth, and had business dealings with him, gives a good account of him.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed; regarding the Missionary Festival at Wakefield. Written from Sheffield.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed; this letter refers to a hymn composed by Montgomery for the Sunday School Union.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed; regarding a new edition of Montgomery's poems. He acknowledges receipt of twenty-five copies of same. Affixed to this letter is a newspaper clipping regarding Montgomery's pension.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed; regarding a course of lectures which Montgomery has been asked to deliver.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed; dealing with a meeting of the Board of Governors, at which Mr. J. Law was appointed House Surgeon. Montgomery returns the unsuccessful applicant's testimonials.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Facsimile of letter written by Montgomery on his 80th birthday. This letter was given (with last page in facsimile) to Sheffield Weekly News , August 11, 1900.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Autograph letter, signed; to his publishers requesting they send him copies of his hymns bound in purple morocco.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by title of work, or first line of text.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Covering a number of items amounting to Â£9.2.6. With some notes by the Rev. Hunter on the reverse side.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Includes a copy of Hymns for the Opening of Christ Church, Newark on Trent (1837)

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials note
relatedmaterial.p: See also folders 45, 50, and 139 for additional portraits of Montgomery.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Includes a print of the Chapel at the Moravian Settlement at Fulneck.

did.unittitle: Documents and publications related to Montgomery's death and burial

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Includes a copy of The Death of James Montgomery, Esq. with a Sketch of his Life (1854)

did.unittitle: Articles and clippings about Montgomery and Sheffield
